qas.question: What cultural group has dominated the PLP?
Who are two prominent members of the PLP?

answers.text: Dame Lois Browne-Evans, and her Trinidadian-born husband, John Evans

qas.question: What are Dame Lois Browne-Evans and her husband putting an emphasis on?

answers.text: Bermuda's cultural connections with the West Indies

qas.question: Why are some Bermudians against the emphasis of West Indies cultural connections?

answers.text: Many Bermudians, both black and white, who lack family connections to the West Indies

context: The PLP, the party in government when the decision to join CARICOM was made, has been dominated for decades by <a0_0><b4_0>West Indians and their descendants.<b4_0/><a0_0/> (The prominent roles of West Indians among Bermuda's black politicians and labour activists predated party politics in Bermuda, as exemplified by Dr. E. F. Gordon). The <b5_0>late PLP leader<b5_0/>, <a1_0><b6_0>Dame Lois Browne-Evans<b6_0/>, and her Trinidadian-born husband, John Evans<a1_0/> (who co-founded the West Indian Association of Bermuda in 1976), were prominent members of this group. They have emphasised <a2_0>Bermuda's cultural connections with the West Indies<a2_0/>. <a3_0>Many Bermudians, both black and white, who lack family connections to the West Indies<a3_0/> have objected to this emphasis.
